{
  "skip": false,
  "country": "global",
  "topic": "sanctions, regulation",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "The FAS has changed its position regarding axitinib, dapagliflozin, ruxolitinib, and osimertinib. Antimonopoly authorities are withdrawing letters explaining the review of tender applications that proposed to supply generics with these active substances. As a result, there is no longer a need to reject such applications. Previously, the Moscow Arbitration Court overturned a FAS decision banning Axelson from entering the market with its ruxolitinib due to a violation of competition protection laws. Earlier, the company successfully challenged similar orders by the generics service for Inlyta (axitinib) from Pfizer and Tagrisso (osimertinib) from AstraZeneca."
}

  "skip": false,
  "country": "Russia",
  "topic": "demand, clinical_trial, guideline",
  "impact": "medium",
  "english": "Analysts have examined the market situation for anticoagulants. According to RNC Pharma data, in Russia, sales of antithrombotic drugs increased by 6.3% in monetary terms and 1.7% in physical units this year, totaling 58.3 million packages and 49.3 billion rubles. The majority (over 57%) of the monetary volume is accounted for by direct inhibitors of factor X, with three main drug names. This category showed the highest growth rate in terms of packages (+16%). The success was mainly due to rivaroxaban drugs, where consumers are actively switching from Bayer's patented Ksarelto to direct analogues. By August 2025, generics have already surpassed the sales volume of the original drug. Pfizer's Ellicvis also saw a rise in sales. Original Russian inhibitor factor X ‚Äî Dimolgin from Avexima ‚Äî has not yet entered the top-10. To achieve success in this category, manufacturers need to significantly invest in promotion. Sales

Earlier, the main oncologist of the Ministry of Health Andrei Kaprin explained that at the initial stage, NeoOncoV can be used in adults with unresectable or metastatic melanoma skin in combination with immunotherapy. The order for obtaining personalized mRNA vaccine will be detailed later."

{
  "skip": false,
  "country": "global",
  "topic": "import_export, sanctions, shortage",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "A parliamentary request from the 'Akjol' faction about border issues has led to delays and high costs for businesses importing fruits and vegetables through Bakhdat and Black River. The authorities require mandatory laboratory testing of every vehicle, regardless of its cargo condition, which is not legally justified and contradicts international rules. As a result, businesses are forced to pay up to 300,000 tenge per vehicle, causing transportation delays and increasing the risk of spoilage for perishable goods. The 'Akjol' faction demands: - Bring the phytosanitary control practice in line with KTS ‚Ññ318 norms; - Provide legal assessment of mandatory laboratory testing of every vehicle; - Review expert fees and ensure transparent pricing; - Check the situation at Black River crossing, including unloading and storage procedures."
}

{
  "skip": false,
  "country": "Kazakhstan",
  "topic": "inflation, demand, clinical_trial",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "The survey conducted by the National Bank of Kazakhstan shows that despite official statements about 'slowing inflation', people still feel an increase in prices across various categories. The actual inflation rate in November was 12.4%, while expectations for short-term price increases are at 13.6% and long-term at 14.9%. This indicates that inflation has become a norm, with many consumers feeling uncertain about the stability of prices. Major concerns include rising costs of basic goods such as food (especially meat, fruits, and vegetables), medicines, and clothing. The survey also notes some stabilization in utilities but increasing costs for internet and mobile services."
}

{
  "skip": false,
  "country": "global",
  "topic": "regulation, vaccine, safety",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "The FDA is relaxing drug approval rules but wants to tighten them for vaccines in the US. The agency allows drugs after one large clinical trial instead of two, aiming to speed up innovation and reduce costs for pharmaceutical companies. However, within the agency there's a push towards stricter regulations, even for flu and COVID-19 vaccine updates. Director of the vaccine division Vinay Prasad suggests mandatory extensive trials, citing unconfirmed deaths after vaccination. Former FDA leaders call this dangerous, saying it will slow new vaccines and cost millions. The debate is about where to draw the line between speed and safety in drug approvals."
}

{
  "skip": false,
  "country": "Kazakhstan",
  "topic": "tenders, import_export, shortage, demand, vaccine, clinical_trial",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "A controversy has arisen around the procurement of vaccines after public figure Dida Samgulov claimed that the Ministry of Health purchased Sanofi vaccines for almost 150 billion tenge. He also suggested that the selection process may have been influenced by lobbying. These issues, including transparency in procurements and justification of vaccine choices, became a subject of wide public discussion. The Ministry of Health rejected these accusations, stating that the vaccines are scientifically justified, comply with SAGE/WHO recommendations, and are used in the national immunization schedule. The context highlights that in 2018, SEC reported on corruption practices by Sanofi in several countries, including Kazakhstan. Therefore, public attention to large procurements from this company is heightened. Additional controversy surrounds the types of vaccines: whole-cell (wP) are more reactive but better control the transmission of pertussis, while acellular (aP) are easier to administer but may not as effectively contain infection and require more frequent revaccinations. The selection between these types requires

{
  "skip": false,
  "country": "global",
  "topic": "regulation, reimbursement, safety, clinical_trial",
  "impact": "medium",
  "english": "This discussion focuses on choosing between etoricoxib and naproxen for quick and safe pain relief. Both are effective but differ in their onset of action (20-25 minutes vs 15 minutes), duration of effect (up to 24 hours vs twice daily), and safety profiles, which affect the recommendation. Etoricoxib is better tolerated by the gastrointestinal tract with a lower risk of serious complications like ulcers or bleeding. Naproxen has a favorable cardiovascular profile but requires twice-daily dosing. The choice depends on patient history: for GI risks, etoricoxib is preferred; for cardiac risks, naproxen is recommended. Both have comparable pain relief efficacy but different safety profiles."
}

{
  "skip": false,

  "topic": "hospital_policy, shortage",
  "impact": "medium",
  "english": "Ardak Amangeldyev, a former vice-minister of health who worked in the financial sphere for over a year, resigned from his position. This is the second major resignation in December, following Aida Kulesseitov's departure as chairman of the Social Medical Insurance Fund after eight months. These resignations occur against the backdrop of a financial crisis in the healthcare system where hospitals are still treating patients in debt and the fund owes hundreds of billions of tenge to clinics. The Ministry of Health is searching for new leaders."
}

  "english": "The digital service 'Social Wallet' has provided over 13 million services for the issuance of medicines in a convenient digital format. This accounts for 81.2% of all prescriptions issued under ambulatory drug supply (ADL) in Kazakhstan. The project is now available to 708 medical organizations across the country. Overall, the level of medication provision has reached 85.1%, including prescriptions dispensed through e-Densaulyq, Halyk, VCK, Face ID and SMS-code mechanisms. 14.9% of prescriptions are still issued in a traditional paper format - this is important for citizens without smartphones or internet access, as well as those with mobility issues, elderly people, children, etc. The entire process of obtaining medications is fully automated: the doctor forms a prescription in the MZR Kazakhstan ISLO system, which automatically appears in the eGov mobile app's electronic voucher format. {
  "skip": false,
  "country": "Kazakhstan",
  "topic": "epidemic,safety,vaccine",
  "impact": "medium",
  "english": "In the first ten months of 2025, only three people who completed a full course of vaccination against measles in Kazakhstan have contracted measles. This information was provided by the Committee for Sanitary and Epidemiological Control in response to a query from Informburo.kz. Since the beginning of this year, 390 cases of measles were reported, including 383 children and seven adults. Among them: 346 individuals did not receive vaccination; three completed the full course of vaccinations; 33 had not finished their immunization process; eight have unknown vaccination history. For measles vaccination in the first ten months of this year, 246 thousand children under one year old (82.1% coverage), 267.7 thousand children aged one year (coverage at 78%), and 281.4 thousand children aged six years (coverage at 76.4%) have been vaccinated. The optimal level of coverage is 79.2%. "
}

{
  "skip": false,
  "country": "Kazakhstan",
  "topic": "demand,safety,vaccine",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "Almost 19,000 Kazakhstani citizens officially refused vaccinations from the beginning of 2025. This is significantly more than eight years ago when around five thousand cases were reported. The main expert at the Committee for Sanitary and Epidemiological Control of the Ministry of Health of Kazakhstan, Madina Oryspayeva, noted that any refusal to vaccinate affects a decrease in collective immunity. Such situation may lead to outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases. Most refusals were recorded in Astana, Almaty, as well as Atyrau and Mangistau regions. People most often cite the same reasons: doubts about the quality of vaccines, lack of information, religious or ideological beliefs."
}

  "topic": "demand, epidemic, vaccine",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "Global charitable organizations and groups have offered to allocate $1.9 billion USD for polio eradication efforts. This funding will annually protect 370 million children from the virus. By 2026, the Global Polio Eradication Initiative's budget is expected to decrease by 30%, with a deficit of $1.7 billion USD by 2029. The reduction in financial support has been caused by countries like the US withdrawing from funding programs. Countries such as Germany and the UK have announced reductions in their contributions, creating additional uncertainty regarding future financing for polio eradication efforts."
}

  "topic": "clinical_trial, demand, epidemic",
  "impact": "high",
  "english": "The report discusses the current state of the Russian retail market for veterinary drugs in Q1-Q3 2025. Key findings include a total retail sales value of 38.3 billion rubles (including VAT) and an annual growth rate of 16.1%. The online channel is driving stunted sales in traditional offline stores, particularly in Moscow and Saint Petersburg. Online market share has increased to 28.6% from 8.9% in 2022. Russian manufacturers have shown significant growth (+37%) compared to foreign brands which lost 30%. The report highlights the increasing inflation rate (13.3%) and rising prices of domestic products faster than imported ones. It also mentions a decrease in product variety from 1883 to 1855 brands over one year."
}
